conclusion: To solve for the tensions in the three ropes OP, OA, and OB, we need to analyze the forces acting on each object and point in the system.
Object A is hanging vertically from rope OA. The only forces acting on A are its weight m_A g and the tension F_TOA in the rope OA.
Since A is in equilibrium, F_TOA = m_A g.
Given m_A = 5 kg and g = 10 m/s^2, F_TOA = 5 x 10 = 50 N.
At point O, there are three forces acting: F_TOA (downward), F_TOP (along the rope OP), and F_TOB (horizontal along the rope OB). Point O is also in equilibrium.
We can resolve F_TOP into its horizontal and vertical components: Horizontal component: F_TOP cos(45°), Vertical component: F_TOP sin(45°).
Horizontal equilibrium: F_TOP cos(45°) = F_TOB, F_TOB = F_TOP x 1/sqrt(2).
Vertical equilibrium: F_TOP sin(45°) = F_TOA, F_TOP x 1/sqrt(2) = 50, F_TOP = 50 sqrt(2).
Using F_TOB = F_TOP x 1/sqrt(2), F_TOB = 50 sqrt(2) x 1/sqrt(2) = 50 N.
The tensions in the three ropes are: F_TOP = 50 sqrt(2) N ≈ 70.71 N, F_TOA = 50 N, F_TOB = 50 N.
